tutorial.title: Car Rental Search
tutorial.descriptionContent: Practice your SQL Filters skills by filtering out a database of rental cars

executableContent.instructions:
You've recently been contacted by a family of six planning a trip to see Yosemite National Park. They're visiting in December, so they want to make sure they'll have a reliable vehicle should there be any inclement weather.

You pull up the agency's database and query out your vehicle inventory to begin assessing options. 

1. Write a query that selects all of the rows and columns from the `cars` database.

From first glance, you notice that some vehicles are not available. Let's get rid of those.

1. Add a `WHERE` condition to your SQL query to filter out the unavailable models.

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Examine the `no_available` column which refers tot the number of vehicles available. We want that number to be a positive number bigger than zero.

executableContent.instructions:
Grandma will be joining the family, so they'll need a car with at least 5 seats.

1. In addition to filtering out the unavailable cars, filter down to the models with 5 or more seats.

files.name: script.sql

executableContent.instructions:
Great, we're down to some really good options. Let's address the other customer concern: inclement weather. Typically, you suggest a car with all-wheel drive. 

1. Add a third condition to filter the list down to cars with "AWD" in the list of `features`.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND features LIKE '%AWD%'

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: You can use the `%` operator in conjunction with a `LIKE`operator to represent "one or more characters". Wrap your search term in wildcard characters to check if `features` contains the text "AWD" anywhere.

executableContent.instructions:
That's not a lot of options, let's also include front-wheel drive vehicles that have winter tires. We'll need to include this in the same condition statement as the "AWD" filter, so we'll wrap our existing SQL in parentheses. Let's start by also showing FWD vehicles. 

1. First, wrap the "AWD" filter ( `features LIKE '%AWD%'` ) in parentheses.
2. Next, add the `OR` operator immediately following the "AWD" filter.
3. Then, add the condition to search the `features` column for the text "FWD". Wrap this statement in parentheses as well.
4. Finally, wrap the two filters (separated by OR) in parentheses.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND features LIKE '%AWD%'
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%'))

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's add the check for "winter tires" to the "FWD" filter. Both conditions will need to be satisfied for a car to be included in the query output.   

1. Add an AND operator right after `features LIKE '%FWD%' ` but before the closing parenthesis.
2. Now, inside the same parenthesis, use the `LIKE` operator to check for "winter tires" in the features column.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%'))
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, the family has specified that they have a $200-$300/day budget. Your database stores prices in string format, so you'll need to use wildcards to appropriately search. Let's first tackle filtering down to cars within the $200/day range. 

1. Modify your query to search for cars with prices in the $200 range. Wrap this condition in parentheses following the `AND`.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
AND (price LIKE '$2%')

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Cars with a `price` in the $200 range will always start with the characters `$2`.

executableContent.instructions:
Now, let's include cars in the $300/day price range, in a similar fashion to how we filtered down to the $200/day cars. Be sure to pay attention to the parantheses.

1. Add a new condition following the `price LIKE '$2%'` condition, separated by an OR, that searches for cars in the $300 range. This condition should be within the same set of parentheses.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
AND (price LIKE '$2%')
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
AND (price LIKE '$2%' OR price LIKE '$3%')

hints.title: Hint
hints.content: Cars with a `price` in the $300 range will always start with the characters `$3`.

executableContent.instructions:
Finally, it would be inappropriate to rent a gas-guzzler for a trip to a beautiful National Park. 

1. Add a filter to only select cars that get between 20 and 30 miles per gallon.

files.name: script.sql
files.content:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
AND (price LIKE '$2%' OR price LIKE '$3%')
files.solvedContent:
SELECT * FROM cars
WHERE no_available > 0
AND seats >= 5
AND ((features LIKE '%AWD%') OR (features LIKE '%FWD%' AND features LIKE '%Winter Tires%'))
AND (price LIKE '$2%' OR price LIKE '$3%')
AND mpg BETWEEN 20 AND 30
